# New medication for diabetes, including what’s in the pipeline for 2025

Credentialled Diabetes Educator Carolien Koreneff reviews new medications and treatments available, or soon to be available, for treating type 1 and type 2 diabetes.

## New developments for people with (or at risk of) **type 1 diabetes**

#### Baricitinib

Baricitinib, also known as Olumiant, is a medication that is mainly used to treat rheumatoid arthritis. It is sometimes also used to treat severe hair loss and even COVID-19. Baricitinib works by blocking the action of Janus kinase enzymes, which are involved in the inflammation process. Baricitinib helps the immune system work better.

The [Baricitinib in New-onset Type 1 Diabetes (BANDIT) study](https://clinicaltrials.gov/study/NCT04774224) showed that people with type 1 diabetes who took baricitinib showed improved glucose levels and decreased insulin requirements, as well as preservation of beta cell function. Most participants still needed to take at least some insulin and needed to continue to monitor their glucose levels. But, after one year of treatment, it seems that the (off-label) use of baricitinib for type 1 diabetes may benefit some people if certain criteria are met.

The Australasian Type 1 Diabetes Immunotherapy Collaborative (ATIC) made several recommendations to healthcare professionals to guide the use of Baricitinib. These include pre-treatment tests to confirm the diagnosis of type 1 diabetes and the presence of residual beta cell function, and follow up tests to check the response after six months by measuring beta cell function, insulin use, CGM metrics and HbA1c. The ATIC statement also mentioned that baricitinib treatment would need to be ongoing. It is particularly important not to miss any doses, to sustain any of the benefits of the medication. However, there is currently no data on the treatment’s effect beyond a year.

Baricitinib is not recommended during pregnancy, for women planning to become pregnant, or while breastfeeding. Also, the use of Baricitinib would be off-label, which means that it is not covered by any PBS subsidy. A private prescription for 28 tablets is listed as costing $1046.

#### Januse kinase (JAK) inhibitors

There are two different treatments, also Januse kinase (JAK) inhibitors like Baricitinib, which are currently being trialled, in what is known as the JAK POT T1D study.

**Abrocitinib** and **Ritlecitinib** are being tested to see if they can preserve insulin production in younger people (aged 12-35) newly diagnosed with (stage 3) type 1 diabetes. Continuing to make even a small amount of insulin can help keep blood glucose levels in the target range, lowering the risk of long-term complications.

If either or both these treatments are successful, these JAK inhibitors may be studied in earlier stages of type 1 diabetes, to see if they can prevent or delay clinical diagnosis. For more information see: [https://www.trialnet.org/our-research/newly-diagnosed-t1d/jakpot-t1d](https://www.trialnet.org/our-research/newly-diagnosed-t1d/jakpot-t1d).

#### Lantidra

The Food & Drug Administration of America (FDA), has approved [Lantidra](https://www.lantidra.com) (Donislecel), a new treatment for people with type 1 diabetes who experience frequent, severe hypoglycaemia.

This first-ever cell therapy works by infusing beta cells (the cells in the pancreas that produce insulin) from donors, into the hepatic portal vein. Once the newly infused beta cells start making insulin, the need for insulin injections, or insulin via pumps, may be eliminated. This transplanting of islet cells means that immune-suppressive medications are needed to avoid rejection.

Early data from the Lantidra trial showed that most participants gained some level of insulin independence. However, it is still uncertain if the benefits of Donislecel are greater than the safety risks. About 87% of study participants experienced infections, and there were complications after surgery, such as cuts on the liver, bruising of the liver, and anaemia.

#### Stem cell treatments

There are two main methods for generating new and functional beta cells: transplanting beta cells from human donors (for example Lantidra, as in the example above) and generating beta cells from stem cells.

Although both methods could be considered functional cures for type 1 diabetes, both methods require the person to take immune-suppressant medications (also known as anti-rejection medications) for the rest of their lives. This is to avoid these new beta cells from being attacked by the person’s own immune system, similar to how their original beta cells got destroyed.

However, researchers think that they may be able to alter the genetic code of implanted cells, so that they can avoid recognition by the immune system. This would mean that they may evade an immune system attack. Pre-clinical trials (done in test-tubes and on animals) had minimal side effects and seemed to be well-tolerated. Clinical trials are being conducted in this area, so watch this space for future updates. Find out more [here](https://diatribe.org/diabetes-research/viacyte-and-crispr-introduce-new-stem-cell-therapy-type-1-diabetes).

## New developments relating to **both people with type 1 and people with type 2 diabetes**

#### Needle-free insulin

An international team, led by [researchers from Sydney University and Sydney Local Health District](https://www.sydney.edu.au/news-opinion/news/2024/05/02/nanotech-opens-door-to-future-of-insulin-medication.html) (SLHD), have developed an oral insulin which may offer a needle-free alternative to insulin in the future.

Previous attempts at making oral insulin failed as the tablets, or capsules, were either too large or broke down prematurely in the stomach. This new technology encapsulates the insulin in nano-carriers, particles 1/10,000th the width of a human hair. Scientists have created a special coating that protects the insulin from being broken down until it reaches the liver. Once the coating is broken down by liver enzymes (that are only active when the blood glucose levels are high), the insulin will either store glucose in the liver, as it would in people who do not have diabetes, or the insulin will enter the bloodstream to rapidly move to areas of the body that need it most.

It is said that this nanotechnology can lower blood glucose levels without causing a low blood glucose level. Interestingly, the new insulin can be eaten by taking a capsule or within a piece chocolate as they did in the trials on baboons.

[Animal studies are completed and scientists are ready to trial this new insulin on humans in 2025](https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2024/01/240119122649.htm#:~:text=Researchers%20have%20found%20a%20new,tested%20on%20humans%20in%202025.). It will be at least a few years before needle-free insulin will be available commercially.

#### Microbiome

In the past 10 years or so lots of research has highlighted the important role microbes (micro-organisms) play. The human microbiome (communities of micro-organisms such as fungi, bacteria, and viruses), especially the gut microbiome, has been linked to multiple chronic conditions, including diabetes.

It may be a strange story, but Dutch researchers proved that [transferring microbiome from a healthy person to the gut of a person with diabetes](https://gut.bmj.com/content/70/1/92), through what is called a faecal transplant, can result in short-term improvement of insulin resistance. This has led to some companies trying to develop diabetes treatments that target the microbiome.

[Microbiome research](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/38078135/) is still in its infancy and appears to be a difficult area of research; it is expected to take perhaps another decade for major developments in this space to result in readily available options.

## New developments for people with (or at risk of) **type 2 diabetes**

#### Mounjaro

Mounjaro was approved by the TGA for the management in type 2 diabetes in 2023.  It is now also approved for use in chronic weight management.

Additionally, Mounjaro is now available in a [multi-dose, pre-filled pen device](https://www.tga.gov.au/safety/shortages/medicine-shortage-alerts/update-supply-mounjaro-tirzepatide-injections). It is important to note, that your pharmacist cannot dispense the Mounjaro KwikPen using a prescription for the vial, so if you are switching to the KwikPen you will need a new prescription.

Unfortunately, all strengths of Mounjaro vials will continue to be limited into 2025, “due to an unexpected increase in demand”. The TGA also reports that it is not known what impact the introduction of the Mounjaro KwikPen, and the new indication for chronic weight management, will have on the overall availability of Mounjaro products. The [Medicine Shortage Reports Database](https://apps.tga.gov.au/Prod/msi/Search/Details/tirzepatide) lists the latest supply status of the different strengths available.

To help during the shortage of Mounjaro vials, the TGA has approved the temporary supply of an overseas-registered tirzepatide product, Mounjaro KwikPen (UK) and they recommend that, if patients are unable to fill their script for the correct strength or presentation of Mounjaro in time for their next dose, they should contact their doctor immediately to have their treatment plan reassessed.

#### PATAS

A French biotech company, is developing a medication called PATAS in conjunction with a team of international researchers, including some from Monash University in Melbourne. PATAS targets insulin resistance by rebooting how fat cells use insulin.

PATAS may have the potential to prevent the development of type 2 diabetes. It could also have other health benefits in chronic medical disorders caused by insulin resistance, including cardiac diseases, fatty liver, and the metabolic syndrome.

PATAS works by correcting an abnormality in fat cells by separating two proteins, which are associated with insulin resistance by blocking insulin from initiating glucose uptake. Early studies have shown PATAS to help these cells absorb glucose without needing insulin. Human clinical trials are likely to start in 2025. It could be delivered via a simple injection and possibly via a patch.

#### Rybelsus

Once-daily [Rybelsus](https://www.rybelsus.com) tablets are a prescription medication used to treat type 2 diabetes. The active ingredient in Rybelsus is Semaglutide, a glucagon-like peptide-1 (GLP-1) agonist. This means that it is the same active ingredient as the once weekly injectable GLP-1 medications Ozempic and Wegovy, but in a pill.

Rybelsus stimulates the pancreas to release more insulin when blood glucose levels are high and prevents the liver from making and releasing too much sugar. It also slows gastric emptying, which means food is slower to leave the stomach after eating. As such, Rybelsus is not suitable for people with type 1 diabetes due to the increased risk of hypoglycaemia associated with this delayed gastric emptying.

Rybelsus has the same potential side-effects as injectable Semaglutide: nausea, stomach pain, diarrhoea, decreased appetite, constipation, and weight reduction. This medication was approved by the Therapeutic Goods Administration (TGA) in February 2022, it is not known if or when it will be available in Australia, on the PBS.

#### Sidapvia

Australians with type 2 diabetes are able to access [Sidapvia](https://www.pbs.gov.au/medicine/item/14638K-14645T) through the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme (PBS) as of November 2024. This new listing gives people with type 2 diabetes an additional treatment option.

Sidapvia is a combination medication that has both dapagliflozin (know as Forxiga) and sitagliptin (known as Januvia) in the one tablet. It should be used in combination with Metformin, and alongside a healthy diet and regular physical activity.

It does not normally cause hypoglycaemia, although users may experience a low blood glucose level if taking  this medication in combination with certain other medicines, such as insulin or a sulfonylurea (for example gliclazide, glibenclamide or glimepiride).

Sidapvia is not recommended for use during pregnancy or when breastfeeding. It is also not recommended for use in children or in people with type 1 diabetes.

**Executive Summary**  
Recent advances in diabetes treatment (2022–2024) include the emergence of novel medications and technologies for both type 1 and type 2 diabetes. Key developments involve innovative drug classes (such as JAK inhibitors and liver-selective glucokinase activators), new delivery methods (needle-free insulin), and cell-based therapies, with several promising candidates in late-stage clinical trials or recently approved. While some therapies show substantial potential, issues such as safety, long-term efficacy, cost, and accessibility remain.

---

**Introduction: Context and Scope**  
This synthesis analyzes the latest innovations in diabetes treatments and technologies from 2022 to 2024, focusing on new medications, delivery methods, and clinical trial results for type 1 and type 2 diabetes. The review draws from two recent, credible web sources: Diabetes Qualified (2024) and diaTribe (2024), both recognized for reliable, up-to-date diabetes information.

---

**Main Findings Organized by Themes**

**1. Type 1 Diabetes: Emerging Medications and Therapies**  
- **Baricitinib (Olumiant):** Originally for rheumatoid arthritis, this JAK inhibitor showed in the BANDIT study that it can improve glucose levels, decrease insulin requirements, and preserve beta cell function in new-onset type 1 diabetes. However, it remains off-label, expensive, and requires ongoing use; long-term safety is unknown. (Diabetes Qualified, 2024)
- **Other JAK Inhibitors (Abrocitinib, Ritlecitinib):** Currently in the JAK POT T1D trial for newly diagnosed (stage 3) type 1 diabetes, aiming to preserve endogenous insulin production in younger individuals. If successful, these drugs may be tested for diabetes prevention. (Diabetes Qualified, 2024)
- **Cadisegliatin:** A liver-selective glucokinase activator, now in a phase III clinical trial (CATT1), aims to reduce hypoglycemia when used alongside insulin. Previous studies showed a 40% reduction in severe hypoglycemic events, earning FDA breakthrough therapy designation. (diaTribe, 2024)
- **Lantidra (Donislecel):** Recently FDA-approved cell therapy for people with type 1 diabetes and frequent severe hypoglycemia. It involves islet cell transplantation, offering some insulin independence but with high rates of infection and surgical complications; requires lifelong immunosuppression. (Diabetes Qualified, 2024)
- **Stem Cell Therapies:** Early-stage clinical trials are exploring stem cell-derived beta cell implants. While potentially curative, these also necessitate immunosuppression, though gene-editing approaches may eventually obviate this need. (Diabetes Qualified, 2024)

**2. Cross-Type Innovations (Type 1 and Type 2 Diabetes)**
- **Needle-Free/Oral Insulin:** Nanotechnology-based oral insulin encapsulation has succeeded in animal studies, protecting insulin until liver delivery and activating only when blood glucose is high. Human trials are expected to begin in 2025. (Diabetes Qualified, 2024)
- **Microbiome-Based Therapies:** Fecal microbiota transplantation has shown short-term improvements in insulin resistance. However, the field is nascent, and clinically available options are at least a decade away. (Diabetes Qualified, 2024)

**3. Type 2 Diabetes: New Medications and Combinations**
- **Mounjaro (Tirzepatide):** Approved for both type 2 diabetes and chronic weight management, now available in a multi-dose pen. Ongoing supply shortages may affect access. (Diabetes Qualified, 2024)
- **PATAS:** A novel agent targeting insulin resistance at the fat cell level, potentially preventing type 2 diabetes and treating related metabolic disorders. Human trials are anticipated in 2025. (Diabetes Qualified, 2024)
- **Rybelsus (Oral Semaglutide):** Once-daily oral GLP-1 agonist for type 2 diabetes, offering an alternative to injectable semaglutide. Not yet widely available in Australia. (Diabetes Qualified, 2024)
- **Sidapvia:** A new fixed-dose combination of dapagliflozin (SGLT2 inhibitor) and sitagliptin (DPP-4 inhibitor), PBS-listed in Australia as of November 2024. Must be used with metformin. (Diabetes Qualified, 2024)

---

**Critical Analysis of Evidence Quality**  
- **Clinical Evidence:** Most innovations are supported by early-phase or mid-phase clinical trials, with some (e.g., Lantidra, Mounjaro) having regulatory approvals based on robust data. However, for several therapies (e.g., JAK inhibitors, PATAS, oral insulin, stem cell therapies), long-term efficacy and safety remain to be established.
- **Source Reliability:** Both Diabetes Qualified and diaTribe are reputable, with clear referencing of clinical trials and regulatory updates. However, the Diabetes Qualified article is a secondary source summarizing recent research, not presenting original data.
- **Limitations:** Many treatments are either off-label, in clinical trials, or have restricted access due to cost, regulatory status, or supply shortages. Side effects (e.g., immunosuppression risks with cell therapies, GI side effects with GLP-1 agonists) and safety concerns (e.g., high infection rates with Lantidra) are significant.

---

**Synthesis of Key Insights and Patterns**  
- The diabetes treatment landscape is rapidly diversifying, with a shift toward disease-modifying and adjunctive therapies, not just glucose-lowering drugs.
- There is convergence on immune-modulating approaches (JAK inhibitors, stem cell/gene-editing therapies) for type 1 diabetes, and on combination and oral therapies for type 2 diabetes.
- Non-invasive delivery methods (oral insulin) and microbiome interventions represent promising but still experimental frontiers.
- Accessibility and cost remain major barriers, even as regulatory approvals accelerate.

---

**Limitations and Gaps Identified**  
- Most new therapies, especially for type 1 diabetes, are in early or mid-stage trials with limited long-term data.
- Safety profiles, especially for immune-modulating and cell-based therapies, are not fully established.
- Many therapies are not yet widely available due to regulatory, cost, or supply chain issues.
- Microbiome-based and genetic therapies are not expected to reach clinical practice for years.

---

**Evidence-Based Conclusions**  
- Several promising new medications and technologies for diabetes have emerged since 2022, including JAK inhibitors, liver-selective glucokinase activators, and cell-based therapies for type 1 diabetes, as well as novel oral and combination therapies for type 2 diabetes.
- While some, like Mounjaro and Lantidra, have received regulatory approval, most new agents are still in clinical trials, and their ultimate impact will depend on long-term efficacy, safety, cost, and accessibility.
- The trend is toward more personalized, less invasive, and potentially disease-modifying treatments, but significant barriers remain before these innovations become standard of care.

---

**Future Research Directions**  
- Large-scale, long-term trials are needed to establish the safety and durability of JAK inhibitors, stem cell therapies, and oral insulin.
- Research into immunosuppression-free cell therapies and gene-editing approaches is a priority.
- Further investigation into microbiome-targeted therapies and their mechanisms is warranted.
- Health systems research should address cost, access, and implementation challenges for new diabetes treatments.

# Evidence-Based Standard of Care Treatments for Diabetes: 2023-2024 Guidelines

Based on the search results, here's a summary of current evidence-based standard of care treatments for diabetes with the highest efficacy rates according to recent clinical guidelines and meta-analyses:

## Type 1 Diabetes

**Core Treatment:**
- **Insulin therapy** remains the cornerstone treatment, with no viable pharmacological alternatives
- **Intensive insulin regimens** (multiple daily injections or insulin pump therapy) show highest efficacy for glycemic control
- **Technology integration** with continuous glucose monitoring (CGM) and automated insulin delivery systems significantly improves outcomes

**Emerging Adjunctive Therapies:**
- **Baricitinib (Olumiant)** - JAK inhibitor showing promise in preserving beta cell function in new-onset T1D
- **Cadisegliatin** - Liver-selective glucokinase activator in clinical trials, showing 40% reduction in severe hypoglycemic events
- **Lantidra (Donislecel)** - FDA-approved cell therapy for severe hypoglycemia, though requiring immunosuppression

## Type 2 Diabetes in Youth

**First-line Treatment:**
- **Metformin** for HbA1c <8.5% (moderate hyperglycemia) with lifestyle modifications
- **Insulin** required initially for HbA1c ≥8.5%, ketosis, or acidosis

**Second-line/Add-on Therapies (FDA/EMA approved for youth):**
- **GLP-1 receptor agonists:**
  - **Liraglutide** - HbA1c reduction of 0.64% at 26 weeks (ETD: 1.06%)
  - **Exenatide** - HbA1c reduction of 0.36% at 24 weeks (ETD: 0.85%)
  - **Dulaglutide** - HbA1c reduction of 0.9% at 26 weeks (ETD: 1.5%)

- **SGLT-2 inhibitors:**
  - **Empagliflozin** - HbA1c reduction of 0.17% at 26 weeks (ETD: 0.84%)
  - **Dapagliflozin** - HbA1c reduction of 0.25-0.62% (ETD: 0.75-1.03%)

**Surgical Option:**
- **Bariatric surgery** for youth ≥12 years with BMI ≥35 kg/m² and inadequate glycemic control with medications

## Type 2 Diabetes in Adults

**Stepwise Approach Based on ADA 2023 Standards:**
1. **Metformin** remains first-line pharmacotherapy with lifestyle modifications
2. **Cardio-renal protective agents** recommended early, especially for high-risk patients:
   - **GLP-1 receptor agonists** (semaglutide, dulaglutide, tirzepatide)
   - **SGLT-2 inhibitors** (empagliflozin, dapagliflozin, canagliflozin)

**Key Updates in 2023-2024 Guidelines:**
- Emphasis on **higher weight loss goals** (up to 15%) with newer medications
- Expanded role of **SGLT-2 inhibitors** in heart failure management
- Role of **finerenone** for diabetic kidney disease with albuminuria
- Lower **LDL goals** for high-risk individuals
- Consideration of **social determinants of health** in treatment planning

**Innovative Treatments:**
- **Tirzepatide (Mounjaro)** - Dual GIP/GLP-1 receptor agonist with superior efficacy for glycemic control and weight loss
- **Oral semaglutide (Rybelsus)** - First oral GLP-1 RA
- **Fixed-dose combinations** like Sidapvia (dapagliflozin + sitagliptin)

## Glycemic Targets

- **Type 1 and Type 2 Diabetes in Youth:** HbA1c target <6.5% optimal if achievable without significant hypoglycemia
- **Adults:** HbA1c <7% for most, with individualization based on comorbidities and hypoglycemia risk

## Comprehensive Care Approach

Both ISPAD and ADA guidelines emphasize:
- Regular screening for complications (retinopathy, nephropathy, neuropathy)
- Aggressive management of cardiovascular risk factors
- Mental health support and addressing social determinants of health
- Technology integration when appropriate and accessible

The guidelines highlight the importance of individualized, patient-centered approaches to diabetes management, with treatment decisions based on efficacy, safety, cost, patient preferences, and comorbidities.
